The patient was seen on 01/29/2065. I confirm that I have
interviewed and examined the patient, reviewed the resident's
documentation on the patient's chart, and discussed the
evaluation, plan of care, and disposition with the patient.
CHIEF COMPLAINT: "Foot infection."
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 46-year-old man
with a history of insulin-dependent diabetes, blood sugars in the
140s this week, chronic renal insufficiency on hemodialysis
secondary to diabetes who had a bilateral TMA who presents with 3
days of right heel ulcer, discharge and foul smelling order. No
erythema. The patient had decreased sensation in bilateral feet
secondary to diabetic neuropathy. He denies nausea, vomiting,
fevers, abdominal pain, cough, shortness breath, or chest pain.
The patient is blind and speaks Spanish. He also has a history
of hypertension.
The rest of the past medical history, social history, family
history, surgical history, review of systems, allergies, and
medications as per the resident's note.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Temperature is 98.2, pulse 78, respiratory
rate 20, blood pressure is 201/104, and saturation 99% on room
air. General: No apparent distress, cooperative. HEENT:
Normocephalic and atraumatic. Pupils were bilateral cataract
blindness. Conjunctivae were clear. Oral mucosa was moist.
Neck is supple. Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no
wheezes or crackles. Cardiac exam: Regular rate and rhythm. No
murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Abdominal exam: Good bowel sounds,
nondistended, nontender, and soft. Extremity exam: No ankle
edema, calf tenderness, or asymmetry. Musculoskeletal
examination: The patient has bilateral TMA. Skin exam: The
patient has dry gauze at soles of his bilateral feet; however, he
has a 1 cm diameter ulceration in the heel of his right foot that
is crusty and has some yellowish discharge on gauze. It indeed
has foul odor. It is nontender. Neurological examination:
Motor strength 5/5 throughout all extremities. Sensation
decreased bilateral feet, to the ankles. Rest of the lower
extremities were intact to light touch and symmetrical. Vascular
examination 2+ radial and DP pulses.
EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT COURSE: A 46-year-old man diabetic with
foul smelling foot ulcer. Possible diagnoses is cellulitis, soft
tissue infection, or osteomyelitis. The patient's WBC was 6.2.
Hematocrit and platelets were normal. He was slightly dry. His
BUN was 40. His creatinine of 7.4; however, it was decreased
from his hemodialysis yesterday. Sodium was 139, potassium was
5.0. An x-ray of his foot of the right did not reveal any
osteomyelitis; however, given his four smelling odor and
yellowish discharge on his dressing, we elected to treat him with
3.375 mg of Zosyn. He also received Tylenol for some pain. The
patient blood pressure remained high and at one point it was
232/109. He received 10 mg of hydralazine, 10 mg of labetalol IV
as well as 100 mg of labetalol p.o. The patient's blood pressure
went down to 140/82 prior to admission. The patient's primary
care physician was called who agreed with the admission to the
Medical Service.
DIAGNOSES:
1. Diabetic foot ulcers.
2. Hypertension.
